sentences.text: Presidential elections were held in Algeria on 7 September 2024. Originally scheduled for December 2024, they were brought forward by President Abdelmadjid Tebboune. Tebboune was challenged by Youcef Aouchiche of the Socialist Forces Front and Abdellah Hassan Cherif of the Movement of Society for Peace. Tebboune won a second term in office. Conflicting reports about the election's turnout by the National Independent Electoral Authority led to criticism from the three candidates. Aouchiche and Cherif challenged the results.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-03-21 |title=Algeria president sets presidential election for Sept 7 |url=https://arab.news/js6sj |access-date=2024-03-25 |website=Arab News |language=en}}</ref>

<ref name=F24>{{Cite web |date=2024-03-21 |title=Algeria's Tebboune sets 'early' presidential elections for September 7 |url=https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20240321-algeria-s-tebboune-sets-early-presidential-elections-for-september-7 |access-date=2024-03-25 |website=France 24 |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 21 March 2024 the office of incumbent President Abdelmadjid Tebboune announced that the election would be held on 7 September. This announcement was unexpected, as the election had been anticipated to occur in December as they were in 2019 Algerian presidential election|2019.

references.text: <ref name=F24/> Tebboune later explained that the date was the optimal time to hold the election "because it coincides with the end of the summer vacations and the start of the new school year", hereby ensuring high turnout. However, some have questioned the logic of the timing, pointing out that a September election would mean that campaigning would be held amid scorching summer temperatures.<ref name="ap1">{{Cite web |date=5 April 2024 |title=Algerians question president for calling an early election without announcing his own campaign |url=https://apnews.com/article/algeria-early-election-abdelmadjid-tebboune-4a46e0c00481c5aa543c783538366d39 |access-date=5 April 2024 |website=Associated Press |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: The President of Algeria is elected using the two-round system; if no candidate had received a majority of the vote in the first round, a second round would have been held. Candidates needed signatures from 600 elected officials or from 50,000 members of the public to be listed on the ballot. For this election, there were around 24.5 million registered voters. This election was administered by the National Independent Electoral Authority, which was established in 2019 as a response to demands from Hirak (Algeria)|pro-democracy protestors. Algeria's Interior Ministry had previously been in charge of elections.

references.text: <ref>[http://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/2456/ People's Democratic Republic of Algeria: Election for President] IFES</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=7 September 2024 |title=In its presidential elections, Algeria prepares for 'business as usual' |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/9/7/in-its-presidential-elections-algeria-prepares-for-business-as-usual |access-date=7 September 2024 |work=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=7 September 2024 |title=Who are the candidates in Algeria's presidential elections? |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/9/6/who-are-the-candidates-in-algerias-presidential-elections |access-date=7 September 2024 |work=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

<ref name="ABC1">{{cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/presidential-candidates-challenge-election-result-algeria-after-vote-113560341 |title=Opposition candidates file court appeal questioning Algerian presidential election outcome |work=ABC News (US)|ABC News |agency=AP}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 11 July Abdelmadjid Tebboune announced his decision to run for a second term.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=12 July 2024 |title=Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune announces reelection campaign |url=https://apnews.com/article/algeria-president-election-db9ca85799b8686f88ea79fe8c9643c2 |access-date=12 July 2024 |work=Associated Press |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Zoubida Assoul, a lawyer and former magistrate, announced her decision to run for president as the leader of the {{ill|Union for Reform and Progress|fr|Union pour le changement et le progrès}} (UCP). A total of 34 people expressed their intention to run for the presidency, including Youcef Aouchiche of the Socialist Forces Front, Abdellah Hassan Cherif of the Movement of Society for Peace; and Sadia Naghzi of the General Confederation of Algerian Enterprises. Prospective candidates were required to collect a minimum number of signatures to register their candidacy before 18 July. The number of candidates was subsequently reduced to 15.<ref name="climate"/>

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=2024-03-01|title=L'UCP de Zoubida Assoul annonce sa participation à la présidentielle de 2024 |url=https://radio-m.net/lucp-de-zoubida-assoul-annonce-sa-participation-a-la-presidentielle-de-2024/ |access-date=2024-03-21|work=radio-m.net |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=12 July 2024 |title=Algeria's President Tebboune declares his intention to run for a second term |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/07/11/algerias-president-tebboune-declares-his-intention-to-run-for-a-second-term/ |access-date=12 July 2024 |work=Africanews |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 13 July Louisa Hanoune of the Workers' Party (Algeria)|Workers' Party announced her withdrawal of her candidacy as president, citing "unfair conditions".

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=14 July 2024 |title=Algeria: Key opposition figure quits presidential race |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/07/14/algeria-key-opposition-figure-quits-presidential-race/ |access-date=14 July 2024 |work=Africanews |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 1 August the attorney general of the court of Algiers announced the opening of an in-depth preliminary investigation concerning the sale of sponsorships by more than 50 elected officials to candidates for the presidential election. The prosecution announced that all the candidates involved will be arrested on the basis of the anti-corruption legislation in force.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=3 August 2024 |title= Afrique Présidentielle en Algérie: la justice accuse de corruption trois candidats dont le dossier a été refusé |url=https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20240803-pr%C3%A9sidentielle-en-alg%C3%A9rie-la-justice-accuse-de-corruption-trois-candidats-dont-le-dossier-a-%C3%A9t%C3%A9-refus%C3%A9 |access-date=3 August 2024 |work=rfi.fr |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: Only three candidates were allowed to appear on the final ballot: Tebboune, Aouchiche and Cherif.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=4 September 2024 |title=Algeria votes amid inflation and boycott, sparking apathy |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/09/04/algeria-votes-amid-inflation-and-boycott-sparking-apathy/ |access-date=4 September 2024 |work=Africanews |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Attendance at campaign events was marred by low turnout due to high summer temperatures. Throughout the election season, Tebboune highlighted his administration's achievements despite corruption and the COVID-19 pandemic in Algeria, while pledging to create 450,000 jobs after he is reelected and raise monthly unemployment benefits for people aged 19 to 40 from 13,000 dinars to 20,000, equivalent to the Algerian minimum wage. Both Hassani and Aouchiche campaigned on allowing greater political and media freedoms, with the latter also promising an amnesty for "prisoners of conscience" and a review of "unjust laws".

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=3 September 2024 |title=Seeking reelection, Algeria's Tebboune touts gains|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/seeking-reelection-algeria-s-tebboune-touts-gains/7769550.html |access-date=5 September 2024 |work=VOA |language=en}}</ref>

<ref name="f24campaign"/> Although the candidates encouraged people to vote, other activists and political parties called for a boycott.<ref>{{cite news| title=Algerian President Tebboune declared winner of presidential election for second term |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/algerian-president-tebboune-declared-winner-of-presidential-election-for-second-term |work=PBS |agency=AP}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 21 July a group of 11 opposition figures released an open letter denouncing what they called "the authoritarian climate" surrounding the election, adding that it was a "rubber-stamp" exercise.

references.text: <ref name="climate">{{Cite news |date=23 July 2024 |title=Prominent Algerian opposition figures blast 'authoritarian climate' ahead of presidential election |url=https://apnews.com/article/algeria-election-opposition-denounce-authoritarian-climate-1979092c65cffdbbc4902c158cd69f6e |access-date=23 July 2024 |work=Associated Press |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Overseas voting, covering around 800,000 Algerians, began on 2 September, while mobile polling stations servicing remote areas of Algeria began operating on 4 September. On 7 September, polling opened at 08:00 and was originally supposed to close at 19:00 before it was extended by an hour. Domestic turnout was estimated to be at around 48%, while turnout in overseas balloting was at 19.6%.

references.text: <ref name="f24campaign">{{Cite news |date=5 September 2024 |title=Algerians to vote as incumbent Tebboune poised for easy victory |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240905-algerians-to-vote-as-incumbent-tebboune-poised-for-easy-victory |access-date=5 September 2024 |work=France 24 |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=7 September 2024 |title=Algeria heads to the polls for presidential elections |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240907-algeria-votes-as-tebboune-eyes-easy-re-election |access-date=7 September 2024 |work=France 24 |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=8 September 2024 |title=Polls close in Algeria's presidential contest as Tebboune eyes re-election |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/9/7/polls-close-in-algerias-presidential-contest-as-tebboune-eyes-re-election |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=8 September 2024 |title=Algeria's 78-year-old president is expected to breeze to a second term in election |url=https://apnews.com/article/algeria-president-election-tebboune-cherif-aouchiche-6b6a6e6350d4719ad9f82751bb63e808 |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=Associated Press |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 8 September opposition candidate Abdelaali Hassani Cherif's campaign stated they recorded instances of voter fraud and election violations, namely that polling station officials inflated the results, failed to deliver vote-sorting records to the candidates' representatives, and instances of proxy group voting.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |last1=Chikhi |first1=Lamine |last2=Elimam |first2=Ahmed |last3=Lawson |first3=Hugh |title=Algerian candidate Hassani Cherif's campaign says it recorded election violations |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/algerian-candidate-hassani-cherifs-campaign-says-it-recorded-election-violations-2024-09-08/ |website=Reuters |access-date=8 September 2024}}</ref>
<ref>[https://www.joradp.dz/FTP/jo-arabe/2024/A2024063.pdf Algeria Official Journal. Pages 8;9.]</ref>

sentences.text: On 10 September, Cherif and Aouchiche filed an appeal at the Constitutional Court of Algeria challenging the results. On 14 September, the court ruled that Tebboune had won the election but found that his share of the vote was lower than initially announced, receiving 84% of the vote instead of around 95%. A record 16% of votes cast were invalid or blank.{{cn|date=September 2024}}

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=Algerian opposition candidates legally challenge provisional results of presidential polls |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/09/11/algerian-opposition-candidates-legally-challenge-provisional-results-of-presidential-polls/ |website=Africanews |access-date=12 September 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |title=Algerian court certifies Tebboune's landslide reelection win |url=https://apnews.com/article/algeria-election-court-confirms-tebboune-victory-c038da8daca9b428971b3c30cbfb57aa |website=Associated Press |access-date=15 September 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |title=Algeria's Tebboune re-elected with 84% of vote, according to official results |url=https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20240914-algeria-s-tebboune-re-elected-with-84-of-vote-according-to-official-results |website=France 24 |access-date=15 September 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Tebboune was inaugurated for his second term on 17 September.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=Algeria’s president sworn in for a second term after lopsided election |url=https://apnews.com/article/algeria-president-election-tebboune-inaugurated-0255105ea3f25a14f4d2b1194e89264c |website=Associated Press |access-date=17 September 2024}}</ref>
